p.s: Sonnet 60 is a typical Shakespearean sonnet written by William Shakespeare.
It is divided in three quatrains with each four lines and one couplet with two lines.
The rhyme scheme of the quatrains is cross rhyme (ABAB CDCD...) and the couplet has a pair rhyme (GG).
Furthermore the sonnet is written in an iambic pentameter.
Because of the wordfields time (compare with ll. 2, 8, 9, 13) and kingdom (compare with ll. 6, 7, 13) you can notice that the sonnet is about the transience of time compared with the life of a king.
THe first quatrain opens with a similiesimile.
The lyrical I compares the waves which come towards the pebbled shore (l. 1) with the time of our lifes.
Both will come to their end (l. 2).
For the waves the beach would be the end and our time will end if we die.
So we human are like waves.
No matter what we do we cannot stop moving to the end.
The metaphor In sequent toil all forwards do contend in line 4 underlines the transience of time.
The lyrical I describes the end of life like final fight and everyone has to fight one last time.
So it means that everything and everyone comes slowly to an end.
The second quatrain compares our lifeslives with the life of a king.
The exaggeration Nativity in line 5 describes the beginning.
At first the king is born.
This birth is compared with the nativity (l. 5) because in past a king or prince had the same worth for society as God or Jesus.
After the birth the future king has to grow up and become a wise adult for getting the crown.
And someday there will be the time for his glory fight (l. 7).
Here the lyrical I makes use of a symbolesymbol.

The king is like us and the glory fight (l. 7) is like the end of our lifeslives so the lyrical I shows that it does not matter if we want this final fight because we cannot change that we will die one day.
The third quatrain underlines the transience of time too.
It opens with personification Time doth transfix the flurish is set on youth in line 9.
With this the lyrical I shows that the time can change rapidly.
The time suddenly stops your youth when you become an adult.
Because of this your life changes very hardly.
The couplet includes the personification And yet to times in hope my verse shall stand (l. 13).
Here the lyrical I explains that the sonnet is adressedaddressed to people who are in this difficult situation of the final fight.
You should not try to hide yourself from this last fight because you will die anyway.
I personally like the sonnet.
It is very hard to understand the message but the topic is very important.
The reader should realize that time is not infinite and someday your life will come to an end no matter what you do.
You cannot hide from it or stop it so you should lifelive in present and enjoy every moment in your life.
I also like the sonnet because Shakespeare was a realist.
It is very spooky to listen or hear that you can die anytime so you have to live every day like it would be the last.
William Shakespeare is not affraid of it and dares to write about it.
